EC numbers
Also called code numbers, enzyme numbers, enzyme code, enzyme commission numbers.
Description
EC numbers consist of one to four numbers separated by dots '.', for example '1.18.1.3', '3.1', '3.2.1.99'. These four parts are of a hierarchical nature, '1.18.1.3' means 'serial number 3 of subsubclass 1 of subclass 18 of class 1'.
The first number is the number of the class.
The second number defines the subclass inside the class.
The third number defines the subsubclass inside the subclass.
The fourth number is a serial number of the enzyme inside the subsubclass.
All four numbers are positive integers.
In the literature, the EC number is always preceded by the letters 'EC' and a space. The IntEnz database does not store the prefix, but may display it on the web pages.
Some non-committee datasources use dashes '-' for empty or unspecified fields, for example '2.1.-.-'. In SWISS-PROT, this is used whenever the enzyme was not classified by the committee. The IntEnz database does not support this spelling. <kirill>'-' stand for unspecified fields because they refer to a specific enzyme with yet unassigned EC number; it is also not clear whether the EC number, if assigned, will start with these class, subclass etc. They do not refer to whole (sub)subclass of enzymes! Not only SWISS-PROT uses the '-' but also EMBL. See also comment below.</kirill>
The EC number is the most widely used entity of the enzyme nomenclature work. Scientists tend to ignore the accepted name and the systematic name, but seem to love the EC number. Every self respecting database with metabolic data uses the EC numbers or has at least crossreferences to them.
Therefore it is quite likely that the most used entry point into the IntEnz is via EC numbers. That is certainly true for hyperlinks from other databases. However, people have difficulties remembering numbers, so interactive access is more likely to be started using some search words or by browsing.
Source
EC numbers are authority of the committee, they are therefore shared without dispute or conflict between the different user views.
However, IntEnz curators will suggest new enzymes, which have to be approved by a committee member or automatically after two months. To implement this automatic approval, the curators have to suggest the first three parts of the EC number.
Domain
An EC number consists of a tuple of four positive integers.
The first number is the number of the class and has the domain ec1.
The second number is the number of the subclass and has the domain ec2.
The third number is the number of the subsubclass and has the domain ec3.
The forth part is an integer number between 1 and ca 300. They start with 1 and increase as needed. It is to be expected that the upper bound increases, but certainly not beyond thousands.
All four parts are nullable. To be exact, only trailing nulls are allowed by the hierarchical nature. For example, 1.2.null.null is an acceptable enzyme number with the meaning class 1, subclass 2, subsubclass and serial number not yet decided. However, 1.null.2.3 is not meaningful. The distinction between EC 1.2.null.null as for enzyme with "not yet assigned" subsubclass and serial number and EC 1.2. as for complete identifier for given class+subclass, should be made clear by the context that uses the EC number.
Constraints
Note: The comments in italics are hints about the implementability and can be safely ignored.
EC numbers are unique. [unique constraint uq_enzyme$ec_quad]
EC numbers are only assigned by the committee. [privileged stored procedure?]
EC numbers are never recycled once they are proposed or accepted by IUBMB and publicised to the general public, for instance on a web page or servlet. On a technical side note, this should be stricly enforced. However, we might have to implement an 'unlocking' procedure to fix the accidental typo or otherwise mistakenly 'used' EC number. [table for used ec numbers, before insert and update trigger checks this table and raises application error if found]
The first, second and third number have to be controlled. In other words, the database should reject EC numbers which refer to a non-existing class, class.subclass, class.subclass.subsubclass tuple. [foreign key cascade]

Classes
Description
This is the highest level of the enzyme hierarchy. There are currently six different classes, 1 to 6. It is unlikely that there will be more classes in future.
Attributes
EC number of the class, example '3'.
Name, example 'Hydrolases'.
Description. A short paragraph explaining the contents of the class. <kirill>Currently, descriptions to classes and subclasses could be found in "Introduction" files, e.g.
http://www.chem.qmul.ac.uk/iubmb/enzyme/EC4/intro.html </kirill>
Status.
In the unlikely event of a new class being created, it has to undergo the approval mechanism, which needs a status flag and a edit history. As with all hierarchy elements, only the committee can create new instances, therefore only PROPOSED, REJECTED PROPOSED and APPROVED are legal states. <kirill>Indeed it is highly unlikely however I don't see why the new hierarchy elements can not be SUGGESTED in principle.</kirill>
Unique identifier
Classes are uniquely identified by their EC number. This number is also the only plausible entry point besides browsing through the classes.
Source
Classes are only assigned by the enzyme committee. The name and description is found on the IUBMB web pages and in the expasy file ENZCLASS.TXT, the contents should be identical, while the spelling and encoding might be slightly different.
Domains
EC number: domain ec1, positive integer. There are currently six different classes, 1 to 6. It is unlikely that there will be more numbers in future, certainly never more than ten.
Name: String, current maximal length 20 characters.
Currently no special characters, but possibly for new classes.
Description: String, current maximal length 745 characters, on average 470 ± 240.
Can contain special characters.
Status: domain status, enumeration.
Constraints
Note: The comments in italics are hints about the implementability and can be safely ignored.
The EC number is unique and mandatory. [unique constraint/primary key]
The EC number is a positive integer. [check constraint]
EC numbers should never be recycled. However, it is doubtful if this has to be enforced, as a new or deleted class is an extremely rare and unlikely event, which is closely watched by the community.
The name is mandatory. [unique constraint]
[not null constraint]
The name doesn't end on a dot, question or exclamation mark. Besides, the name doesn't begin or end with white space. [check constraint]
The description is mandatory. [not null constraint]
The description does end normally on a dot, question or exclamation mark, and it doesn't begin or end with white space. [check constraint]
Classes are only created, renamed and deleted by the committee. [privileged stored procedure?] <kirill>I don't see why the new classes can not be SUGGESTED in principle.</kirill>

Find a class by EC number (many per day).
Is 'a' a valid class number (few per day for referential integrity).
List all classes with number and name (many per day for browsing).

Subclasses
Description
This is the second level of the enzyme hierarchy. A subclass is always part of a class. For example, the subclass EC 3.1 'Acting on ester bonds' is a child of the class EC 3 'Hydrolases'.
Attributes
EC number of the subclass, example '3.1'.
Name, example 'Acting on ester bonds'. This name makes only sense inside it's class.
Description. A short paragraph explaining the contents of the subclass.
<kirill>Currently, descriptions to classes and subclasses could be found in "Introduction" files, e.g.
http://www.chem.qmul.ac.uk/iubmb/enzyme/EC4/intro.html </kirill>
Status.
Unique identifier
Subclasses are uniquely identified by their EC number tuple.
Source
Subclasses are only assigned by the enzyme committee. The name and description is found on the IUBMB web pages and in the expasy file ENZCLASS.TXT, the contents should be identical, while the spelling and encoding might be slightly different.
Domains
EC number: The first part of the EC number is of the domain ec1. The second part of the EC number is of the domain ec2, an positive integer, currently ranging from 1,2,3,...,18,19,97,99. There may be higher numbers in future, but unlikely more than hundreds.
Name: String, current maximal length 177 characters, on average 36 ± 26 characters.
Can contain special characters.
Description: String, current maximal length 1950 characters, on average 460 ± 440 characters. The description is not unique.
Can contain special characters.
Status: domain status, enumeration.
Constraints
Note: The comments in italics are hints about the implementability and can be safely ignored.
The EC number tuple is unique and mandatory. [unique constraint/primary key]
The first EC number has to be a valid class number. [foreign key]
The second EC number is a positive integer. [check constraint]
EC numbers should never be recycled.
The name is mandatory but may be not unique in future. [not null constraint]
The name doesn't end on a dot, question or exclamation mark. Besides, the name doesn't begin or end with white space. [check constraint]
The description is optional and not unique (for example EC 4.99 and EC 5.99 'A subclass of miscellaneous enzymes.') [null constraint]
The description does end normally on a dot, question or exclamation mark, and it doesn't begin or end with white space. [check constraint]
Subclasses are only created, renamed and deleted by the committee. [privileged stored procedure?] <kirill>I don't see why the new subclasses can not be SUGGESTED in principle.</kirill>

Find a subclass by EC number (many per day).

List all subclasses of a given class with number and name (many per day for browsing).

Populate database with subclasses from IUBMB web pages (initial loading).
Create a new subclass, given the class it belongs to, the new name and optionally a description. (rarely).
Delete an existing subclass. All it's children will have been taken care of before the deletion (very rare).
Subsubclasses
Description
This is the third level of the enzyme hierarchy. A subsubclass is always part of a subclass. For example, the subsubclass EC 3.1.1 'Carboxylic ester hydrolases' is a child of subclass EC 3.1 'Acting on ester bonds'.
Attributes
EC number of the subsubclass, example '3.1.1'.
Name, example 'Carboxylic ester hydrolases'. This name makes only sense inside it's subclass.
Description. A short paragraph explaining the contents of the subsubclass.
Status.
Unique identifier
Subsubclasses are uniquely identified by their EC number tuple.
Source
Subsubclasses are only assigned by the enzyme committee. The name and description is found on the IUBMB web pages and in the expasy file ENZCLASS.TXT, the contents should be identical, while the spelling and encoding might be slightly different.
Domains
EC number: The first part of the EC number is of the domain ec1. The second part of the EC number is of the domain ec2 The third part of the EC number is of the domain ec3, an positive integer, currently ranging from 1,2,3,...,29,30,99. There may be higher numbers in future, but unlikely more than hundreds.
Name: String, current maximal length 130 characters, on average 34 ± 24 characters.
Can contain special characters.
Description: String, current maximal length unknown. The description is not unique.
Can contain special characters.
Status: domain status, enumeration.
Constraints
Note: The comments in italics are hints about the implementability and can be safely ignored.
The EC number tuple is unique and mandatory. [unique constraint/primary key]
The first and second EC number has to be a valid subclass number. [foreign key]
The third EC number is a positive integer. [check constraint]
EC numbers should never be recycled.
The name is not mandatory and may be not unique in future. [null constraint]
The name doesn't end on a dot, question or exclamation mark. Besides, the name doesn't begin or end with white space. [check constraint]
The description is optional and not unique. [null constraint]
The description does end normally on a dot, question or exclamation mark, and it doesn't begin or end with white space. [check constraint]
Subsubclasses are only created, renamed and deleted by the committee. [privileged stored procedure?] <kirill>I don't see why the new subsubclasses can not be SUGGESTED in principle.</kirill>
Functions
Find a subsubclass by EC number (many per day).
Is 'a.b.c' a valid subsubclass number (few per day for referential integrity).
What is the subclass number of a given subsubclass? (many per day for browsing).
List all subsubclasses of a given subclass with number and name (many per day for browsing).
What is the next free (and never used) subsubclass EC number. This function has to fill the gaps before the magic numbers 97 and 99 (rarely).
Populate database with subsubclasses from IUBMB web pages (initial loading).
Create a new subsubclass, given the subclass it belongs to, the new name and optionally a description. (rarely).
Transfer an existing subsubclass to another place in the hierarchy. This is rare, but has happened (for example EC 3.1.23). Because of it's rarity, it can probably by implemented as creation of the new subsubclass, transfer of the enzyme, deletion of the old subsubclass with a note of what has happened.(very rare).
Delete an existing subsubclass. All it's children will have been taken care of before the deletion (very rare).
Enzymes
Also called sometimes entries (in the context of enzyme databases).
Description
Enzymes are the main entities of the IntEnz database.
Attributes
One unique EC number, for example '3.1.1.1'.
One unique stable accession number. This accession number is needed to trace suggested enzymes which don't have received an official EC number. It must be stable as it will be used by IntEnz curators to track their work, and it might be used by external databases like SWISS-PROT.
One mandatory accepted name, for example 'carboxylesterase'.
One optional systematic name, for example 'carboxylic-ester hydrolase'. It is entered whenever possible, but for some enzymes a full systematic name would be pointless and is therefore omitted.
Zero or more other names, for example 'ali-esterase; B-esterase; monobutyrase'.
One or more reactions, for example
a carboxylic ester + H2O = an alcohol + a carboxylate
The cardinality was quite difficult to analyse. According to the IUBMB concept, the reaction is defining an enzyme, so one would expect it to be a unique mandatory attribute. However, Kirill found out that this is not exactly true, or, to be more precise, might have to be changed in future.
Some enzymes are not very specific. Rather than targeting a specific substrate, it will deal with a whole set of chemically similar substrates. Currently, this is modelled in the enzyme list with an English description of the set. See for example EC 1.1.3.7, which has the reaction
an aromatic primary alcohol + O2 = an aromatic aldehyde + H2O2
and the comment
Oxidizes many primary alcohols containing an aromatic ring; best substrates are (2-naphthyl)-methanol and 3-methoxybenzyl alcohol
Another example would be
L-homoserine + NAD(P)+ = L-aspartate 4-semialdehyde + NAD(P)H
which is actually a family of two reactions:
L-homoserine + NAD+ = L-aspartate 4-semialdehyde + NADH
L-homoserine + NADP+ = L-aspartate 4-semialdehyde + NADPH
An even stronger indicator are comments like 'can also act on substrate X2'. See for example EC 1.13.11.44, which has the reaction
benzene-1,2,4-triol + O2 = maleylacetate
and the comment
6-chlorobenzene-1,2,4-triol (6-chlorohydroxyquinol) is also a substrate, yielding 2-chloromaleylacetate
Kirill suggested that the latter one should be treated as second(ary) reaction or as a member of an reaction family. See www.ebi.ac.uk/~kirill/ec_reactions.txt
Zero or more comments, for example 'Wide specificity'.
Zero or more cofactors, for example 'Zinc'.
Zero or more crossreferences to other databases, for example 'SWISS-PROT:P14943 (EST2_RABIT)'.
Status.
Unique identifier
The EC number of an enzyme is unique. Normally, it serves beautifully as unique identifier. However, this is only true for approved and proposed enzymes, because suggested enzymes don't have a full EC number. However, the generic identifier can uniquely identify all enzymes in the database.
Source
Data for enzymes are found on the IUBMB web pages and in the expasy file ENZYME.DAT.
Count
Some notes on the number of enzymes and the expected future:
Year Enzymes
1994 3546
1995 3594
1998 3704
1999 3705
2001 3870
This is not too impressive (less than 500 for 5 years). Assuming (unrealistically) 500 new entries next year, 1000 new entries next year, 1500 entries next year etc., we will have increase up to maximum 11,500 entries during the next 5 years.

EC number: The four parts of the EC number are of the domains ec1, ec2, ec3, ec4, respectively.

Reactions
Also called catalytic activity.
See also the specification for enhancement of reacions in IntEnz.
Description
The enzyme nomenclature system is based on classifying the reactions that are catalyzed by the enzymes. The reaction is therefore the defining attribute of an enzyme.
Normally, the reaction is specified as follows:
substrate11 + substrate12 [ + substrate1n] = substrate21 + substrate22 [ + substrate2n]
In some cases free text is used to describe a reaction, for example 'Degrades starch to cyclodextrins by formation of a 1,4-alpha-D-glucosidic bond' and 'Cleaves Leu-|-Leu bond in angiotensinogen to generate angiotensin I'.
Attributes
Textual representation of the reaction equation, for example
L-proline + NAD(P) = 1-pyrroline-2-carboxylate + NAD(P)H
Flag to distinguish chemical equations from free text reactions. Not necessarily stored in the database, as an equal sign '=' is a clear hint for an chemical equation.
This will become important when we extend the database to parse the reaction text using the following operation: in all reactions containing ' = ', extract the entities divided by ' = ' and ' + ' and tag them as chemicals; those on the left of ' = ', are the chemicals with role=reactant, those on the right of ' = ' are the chemicals with role=product.
Status [do reactions have a status?]. <kirill>Why not -- but then I suggest that every field has the status (SUGGESTED, PROPOSED and APPROVED) attribute; EC number can only be PROPOSED or APPROVED.</kirill>
Unique identifier
Reactions are uniquely identified by their textual representation. This text is functionally dependent on the EC number.
Source
The IUBMB web pages list the reactions in a field 'Reaction:'. The expasy file ENZYME.DAT lists the reactions in 'CA' line types. The two sources have different spellings for the special characters, different conventions (H+ etc), and have fixed different errors in their respective versions.
Domains
Textual representation: String.
Equation/free text flag: boolean or one of EQUATION, FREETEXT.
Constraints
Note: The comments in italics are hints about the implementability and can be safely ignored.
The reaction text is not necessarily unique.
The reaction text doesn't end on a dot, question or exclamation mark. Besides, the name doesn't begin or end with white space. [check constraint]
Reactions can be suggested by IntEnz curators, and are proposed and approved by enzyme committee members. [privileged stored procedure?]
Small typographical errors can be corrected without approval.

[It is unclear if the approval of a reaction can be tied to the approval of the full enzyme entry.]

Retrieve reaction text in SWISS-PROT comment line format (CC -!- CATALYTIC ACTIVITY:) for insertion into TrEMBL entries during automatic annotation (quarterly updates of TrEMBL).
Accepted names
Also called description, official name, common name, recommended name.
Description
The recomended name is sufficiently short for general use, but not necessarily very systematic. In a great many cases it is a name already in current use. Accepted names for new enzymes are frequently formed as a condensed version of the systematic name.
Attributes
The accepted name is an attribute of an enzyme and has no attributes itself.
Unique identifier
Accepted names are identified by their textual representation. This text is functionally dependent on the EC number.
Source
The IUBMB web pages list the accepted name in a field 'Common name:'. The expasy file ENZYME.DAT lists it in 'DE' line types. The two sources have different spellings for the special characters, different conventions (H+ etc), and have fixed different errors in their respective versions.
Note: ENZYME.DAT writes accepted names with an initial capital, for example 'Leucyl aminopeptidase.' compared to the IUBMB version 'leucyl aminopeptidase'.
Domains
Textual representation: String.
Can contain special characters.
Constraints
Note: The comments in italics are hints about the implementability and can be safely ignored.
Sinead: The recommended name is unique (it may occur as an 'other name' for some other enzyme but it should be unique for the common-name field. Similarly, the systematic name is occasionally used as the common name for the same enzyme, but no two systematic names should be the same. (In the past we have occassionally given two enzymes the same common name, but once we were aware of the error, we changed one of the names). [unique constraint]
The accepted name doesn't end on a dot, question or exclamation mark. Besides, the name doesn't begin or end with white space. [check constraint]
Accepted names can be suggested by IntEnz curators, and are proposed and approved by enzyme committee members. [privileged stored procedure?]
Small typographical errors can be corrected without approval.

Propose a suggested change (few per day).
Approve a proposed change (few per day).
[It is unclear if the approval of an accepted name can be tied to the approval of the full enzyme entry.]

Promote an 'other name' to the accepted name(few per day).
Optional function for a later stage of the project:
Retrieve reaction text in SWISS-PROT description line format for insertion into TrEMBL entries during automatic annotation (quarterly updates of TrEMBL).
Systematic names
Description
The systematic name of an enzyme is the basis for classification, formed in accordance with definite rules, shows the action of an enzyme as exactly as possible, thus identifying the enzyme precisely.
Attributes
The systematic name is an attribute of an enzyme and has no attributes itself.
Unique identifier
Systematic names are uniquely identified by their textual representation. This text is functionally dependent on the EC number.
Source
The IUBMB web pages list the systematic name in a field 'Systematic name:'. The expasy file ENZYME.DAT does not contain systematic names.
Domains
Textual representation: String.
Can contain special characters.
Constraints
Note: The comments in italics are hints about the implementability and can be safely ignored.
The systematic name is not necessarily unique in the current dataset, but it should be made unique. Sinead: The systematic name is occasionally used as the common name for the same enzyme, but no two systematic names should be the same. [unique constraint]
The systematic name doesn't end on a dot, question or exclamation mark. Besides, the name doesn't begin or end with white space.
Systematic names can be suggested by IntEnz curators, and are proposed and approved by enzyme committee members. [privileged stored procedure?]
Small typographical errors can be corrected without approval.

Other names
Also called alternate names, alternative names, synonyms.
Description
To enable the database to be used for finding recommended names, as many as possible 'other names' that have been used have been included, but are not recommended. Some of these may only have been used to a small extent.
Attributes
Name.
Order in list. It's was decided not to store the order in the database, but generate it on the fly, for instance alphabetically or by date of creation.
Obsolete flag
[The book says on p23 that some other names are so obsolete that they are flagged 'Obs'. It this true for the web pages?] Kirill didn't see it on web pages.
Misleading flag
[The book says on p23 that some other names are misleading and are flagged 'Mis'. It this true for the web pages?] Kirill: It's not true for web pages.
Status
[do reactions have a status?]. <kirill> Why not -- but then I suggest that every field has the status (SUGGESTED, PROPOSED and APPROVED) attribute; EC number can only be PROPOSED or APPROVED. </kirill>
Unique identifier
Other names do not have a natural unique identifier.
Source
The IUBMB web pages list the other names in a field 'Other names:'. The expasy file ENZYME.DAT lists it in 'AN' lines. The two sources have different spellings for the special characters, different conventions (H+ etc), and have fixed different errors in their respective versions.
Note: ENZYME.DAT writes other names with an initial capital.

Textual representation: String.
Can contain special characters.

Note: The comments in italics are hints about the implementability and can be safely ignored.
The other name is not unique.
The other name doesn't end on a dot, question or exclamation mark. Besides, the name doesn't begin or end with white space. [check constraint]
A list of other names for one enzyme must not contain duplicates.
Other names can be suggested by IntEnz curators, and are proposed and approved by enzyme committee members. [privileged stored procedure?]
Small typographical errors can be corrected without approval.

Comments
Description
Comments are free text notes on an enzyme, and may be used to convey any useful information.
Some comments show some structure, for example
Requires X
Also acts on X
An X protein
Not identical with EC x.x.x.x
Attributes
Comment text.
Order in list.
[Other names come normally as a list of size zero to many. We need to decide if we treat it as ordered list or get the order on the fly.]
Status [do comments have a status?]. <kirill> Why not -- but then I suggest that every field has the status (SUGGESTED, PROPOSED and APPROVED) attribute; EC number can only be PROPOSED or APPROVED. </kirill>
Unique identifier
Comments do not have a natural unique identifier.
Source
The IUBMB web pages list the comments in a field 'Comments:'. This field is free text with one or more sentences. The expasy file ENZYME.DAT lists comments in 'CC' lines, separating sentences into multiple comment fields. Furthermore, it lists cofactor comments in 'CF' lines.

Textual representation: String.
Can contain special characters.

Note: The comments in italics are hints about the implementability and can be safely ignored.
The comment is not unique.
The comment ends on a dot (i.e. full stop). Besides, the comment doesn't begin or end with white space. [check constraint]
A list of comments for one enzyme must not contain duplicates.
Comments can be suggested by IntEnz curators, and are proposed and approved by enzyme committee members. [privileged stored procedure?]
Small typographical errors can be corrected without approval.

Cofactors
Description
Cofactors are small molecules required by an enzyme to function properly.
Some enzymes work with a multitude of different cofactors, they are listed as 'a or b'.

CAS registry numbers
Also called CAS numbers, CAS, CASRN.
Description
CAS is the abbreviation of Chemical Abstracts, which is a division of the American Chemical Society. CAS has a registry for chemical substances, which contains more than 32,000,000 substance records, covering scientific literature from 1957 to the present. Each substrace is identified by a unique numeric identifier called a CAS Registry Number.
The CAS registry numbers are universally accepted in nearly all involved databases. They target not directly enzymes, but rather all chemical substances, including the substrates found in the reaction. They are therefore ideally suited for the biochemistry nomenclature component of BioBabel.
Unfortunately, the registry is a commercial database, and the EBI has no license for it. The Trinity College group has some informal connections with CAS. Gill Fraser worked for CAS and might have some contacts.
Example: 58-08-2 is the CAS Registry Number for caffeine.
More information can be found on the CAS website, especially in the document regsys.html [local copy].
Domain
A CAS Registry Number includes up to 9 digits which are separated into 3 groups by hyphens. The first part of the number, starting from the left, has up to 6 digits; the second part has 2 digits. The final part consists of a single check digit.
The check digit and it's algorithm is described on the CAS webside in the document checkdig.html [local copy].
Some less geeky explanation on the topic can be found at ChemFinder [local copy].
The Perl-style regular expression is /[0-9]{1,6}-[0-9]{2}-[0-9]/.
Source
The HTML pages have CAS registry numbers for some of the enzymes in the field 'Links to other databases'.
Furthermore, CAS registry numbers are used by the databases Medline and LIGAND, but surely without guarantee of correctness.

Data comments
Description
Some data need some extra info. For instance, some CAS numbers have had some text included in the CAS number field which avoided the proper validation of it. Thus, that extra info should be independent from - though related to - the data item.
Attributes
Comment text
Comment id: the unique identifier of the comment.
Enzyme id: the unique identifier of the enzyme this comment applies to.
As the comment applies actually to a data item, every data item capable of holding a comment should have an attribute comment id.
Unique identifier
Data comments are uniquely identified by their id (and the enzyme id they apply to, in case of cloned enzymes).
Source
?
Domain
Textual representation: String.
May contain special characters.
Constraints
A data item can hold just one comment.
The comment text is not unique.
